com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.string.joiner
Interface Joiner2

All Superinterfaces:
Joiner2Settings<Joiner2,MapJoiner2>, SharedJoiner2Settings<Joiner2,MapJoiner2>
public interface Joiner2
extends Joiner2Settings<Joiner2,MapJoiner2>

Extension of Google Guava's Joiner. To construct a new instance, see Joiner2Utils.withSeparator(String) and Joiner2Utils.withSeparator(char).

Differences to Joiner:

  • SharedJoiner2Settings.withFormatter(Formatter2): Format each joined element precisely. Easily add a prefix and/or suffix, e.g., new StringFormatter("[%s]")
  • Default text for null values is "null". This matches the behavior of Formatter. By default, class Joiner will throw a NullPointerException when joining a null value, unless Joiner.useForNull(String) is called before joining. This is a source of many surprising/annoying/accidental runtime exceptions.
  • SharedJoiner2Settings.useForNoElements(String): During a join, if no elements are found, this text is used. When joining elements for an exception or log message, "(empty)" is a good value to indicate to (exception and log) readers that no elements were found.
  • Uses interface Joiner2, instead of a concrete class. This follows JavaEE design principles, and is helpful for mocking and testing. Due to Java interface limitations with generic methods, the methods appendTo(Appendable, *) are slightly different from Joiner. The Appendable reference is not a generic type (for input and output).
  • All settings may always be changed, e.g., separator, null text, etc. Class Joiner does now allow these attributes to be set more than once.
  • Settings accessors, e.g., SharedJoiner2Settings.withSeparator().
  • Default settings are available as public static final members, e.g., Joiner2Utils.DEFAULT_NULL_TEXT.

Examples: 

Joiner2Utils.INSTANCE.withSeparator(", ")
     .withFormatter(new StringFormatter("[%s]"))
     .join(list) -> "[a], [b], [c], ..."
 Joiner2Utils.INSTANCE.withSeparator(", ")
     .withFormatter(new StringFormatter("[%s]"))
     .join(listWithNulls) -> "[a], [b], [null], [c], ..."
 Joiner2Utils.INSTANCE.withSeparator(", ")
     .withFormatter(new StringFormatter("[%s]"))
     .skipNulls(true)
     .join(listWithNulls) -> "[a], [b], [c], ..."
 Joiner2Utils.INSTANCE.withSeparator(", ")
     .withFormatter(new StringFormatter("[%s]"))
     .useForNoElements("(empty)")
     .join(emptyList) -> "(empty)"

See SharedJoiner2Settings for an inheritance diagram.

Author:
Kevin Connor ARPE (kevinarpe@gmail.com)
See Also:
Joiner2Utils, Joiner2Settings, MapJoiner2

appendTo

Appendable appendTo(Appendable appendable,
                    Iterator<?> partIter)
                    throws IOException
Appends all remaining elements from an Iterator to an instance of Appendable.

Due to Java interface limitations with generic methods, this method signature is slightly different to Joiner.appendTo(Appendable, Iterator). The Appendable reference is not a generic type (for input and output).

Parameters:
appendable - where to append text. Must not be null.
partIter - stream of elements to join. Must not be null. null elements receive special treatment that depends upon settings from Joiner2Settings.skipNulls() and Joiner2Settings.useForNull().
Returns:
argument appendable (for method chaining)
Throws:
NullPointerException - if appendable or partIter is null
IOException - if appendable throws an IOException
See Also:
appendTo(Appendable, Iterable), appendTo(Appendable, Object[]), appendTo(Appendable, Object, Object, Object...), appendTo(StringBuilder, Iterator), join(Iterator)
